reviewText:
There isn't really a lot to Brainpipe but that's OK. It's a game where you zoom through a tunnel at speed, grab glyphs and avoid anything that's likely to kill you (that's pretty much everything that isn't a glyph, really).

And doesn't it sound so terminally dull when you put it like that? (YES, IT DOES)

Is it terminally dull? Nope. it is so very far from terminally dull! Rejoice.

There's a couple of things that really make Brainpipe special. One is the graphics which, y'know, aren't quite up to the full Minter they're certainly not far off. It's like flying through someone's fevered attempt at a 70's Doctor Who title sequence or what might happen if someone sat down and said Mr Trumbull
date: could you make us a videogame please" or something.\n\nThe other is the sound. Oh man
recommended: the sound. This is the stuff of headphones on
voteText: sit back and enjoy. Or just turn it up really loud if you can't manage that. Parts of the soundtrack wibble in and out of focus
helpfulPercent: sounds zip around you ear to ear
votesHelpful: it's one long Any Colour You Like ride but a little bit more strange.\n\nIt's essentially the full audio/visual woooah there. Which is just fine. I love it to bits. I love it for its simplicity
votesTotal: I love it for its graphics and I love it for its sound but I love it most of all because it's so very pure and unfiltered. It's slightly weirdy
votesFunny: slightly askew and all the woah there. I couldn't ask for much more."
column18: 27 of 28 people (96%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Okay, this game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.

It's the kind of game you play once every few weeks, but for the rest of your life. Great if you randomly feel like immersing yourself in a richly aurally-textured half-axon half-multiverse tunnel with a pace ranging from narcoleptic to highly spasmodic.

The actual goal is collecting glyphes embodying tiered concepts, with a final one marking a progression we'll get back to; all while avoiding obstacles as your speed slowly increases with each level.
For instance, level 1 is the nasal ganglia, with concepts such as peculiar insight" or "nervous laugh" and the final glyph being Awareness.
The gameplay also involves the ability to
recommended: SLOW DOWN TIME. The game really has a particular relation to time in general
hoursPlayed: as you slow down the sound environment as well and pausing temporally stucks you in one audio piece. Said pieces otherwise naturally flow with the game.\n\nWhile all golden glyphes make you "progress"
voteText: and the general goal is to collect everything
helpfulPercent: the game has one and only one condition for winning : collecting the very final glyph
votesHelpful: Unhumanity. Completing a playthrough rewards you with the ability to choose an in-game avatar from a variety of monsters. As for what happens when you miss the glyph... I'll let you see for yourself.\n\nSo in short
votesFunny: love the overall feel of the game
commentsCount: EXTREMELY underrated on steam. It's one of those little games that have a special place in my heart. Maybe literally given the environment."

reviewText:
Classic reflex and control game.  No instructions, but immersion = discovery.
It's weird, trippy, and a bit disjointed, but definitely charming.
You play as the mind's eye in a randomly generated stream of consciousness.
Collect the glyphs for bonus points and strive for that ulitmate goal:  Unhumanity.
No unlocks, no BS.  Simple, yet replayable.
Worth $2?  Yup.  You'll get your playtime out of it.

reviewText:
I found this to be one of the strangest games I have encountered. It is basically a reflex and control game that offer no instructions. There is discovery, which is most of the game experience. Even with that, I still couldn't find myself liking the game.

Perhaps the experience that this game offers is not for me. Maybe I'll try it again someday but not anytime soon.

I give this game a Not my cup of coffee OUT OF 5"."

reviewText:
Quick review:

Short Verdict: A psychedelic first-person runner, with maybe a neuro-something theme if you look hard enough. A bland game experience, and it doesn't add much to the genre. If you really want a runner and don't wanna spend more than US$2 on it, then maybe, just maybe, you could get this. (I wouldn't, since I only had fun for the first 5 minutes of the 15 I managed to play.) Otherwise, stay away.

Pros:
Weird graphics in a nice way
Could be fun as a casual game for the right player
You may start a new game from any stage you want
If you like the game, it has replay value, since levels are randomly generated
Cons:
Controls are not very smooth and don't add much to gameplay
Weird background... music? No, definitely not music, more like organized noises
When it gets too fast, it's almost certain that when you hit an object you'll hit a lot more and die
Health system is kind of weird--when you take a hit, everything shakes and red flashes everywhere, but you can't really know exactly how's your health
Bought on / for: I actually only played BRAINPIPE because I got it as a giveaway. Even for free, I wouldn't get it if I'd known. By the way, it's currently being sold on Steam Store for R$ 4,29 (US$ 1.88).

reviewText: You´re constantly moving forward in a tube (your aim consists of a circle with perpendicular lines moving towards you) , have to avoid obstacles and collect glyphic" items. Pretty relaxing and also good to reduce your brain lag. Improved my reaction time in Counter Strike. I like the esoteric art style and the minimalistic soundtrack. It´s very easy to learn - but as you go along it will be hard to master."

reviewText: Uhmm...  I could write so many reviews for this game but I can't write most of them because the majority would begin with Dude... WTF
date:
only the WTF would be in expletive form.

Anyways.  If you want to feel like a superhero robot in the far away future, with wings made of cotton candy... being sucked down a black hole like a hard boiled egg into a bottle while being possessed by demons and/or possibly yourself... you should buy this game.

If you don't want to feel like that, you should still buy this game.  The game brainwashed me into saying that.  Just kidding.  (It brainwashed me into saying that too.)

IN ALL seriousness, this is a really sick piece of art to check out.  You navigate a translucent eyeball, and I swear I'm being honest this time, through a chaotic bliss of colored shapes and an ever-changing backdrop that gives you both a great challenge and great visual, as well as audio experience.

(P.S. If marijuana is legal in your state/country, you may or may not want to induce before playing... However, I would not suggest tripping while playing this.  If you did, you might actually transport yourself to a parallel dimension.)

reviewText: Never before has the plunge to unhumanity been so compelling, visceral and verticality.

Ah, the smell of highly experimental concepts.

I find this game to be very meditative, at least on the highest levels.
Great sounds, interesting concept, simple gameplay, challenging.
Nice little game.

You are a being of some kind, traveling through some psychedelic pipeline, collecting runes along the way until you achieve a state of unhumanity.  There's 10 runes per level that you have to collect in order to gain a master rune ( I guess). Collecting all 10 runes plus the master rune at the end will elevate you to the next stage of being.

The pipeline does change color and sometimes you hear voices or other audio effects but its all background noise. The music isnt harsh on the ears but I'm not sure I would pop it into the player for hours on end though.  Said pipes are also home to diverse perils, such as green spines sticking out from the side walls, or spinning purple-pink plasma disks, There's also a cage type feature that you have to pass through as well. If you hit any of these obstacles, your display ( if you can call it that) flashes red and you hear a buzzing-warning-klaxon type sound. (very short though)

You do speed up as the levels progress so quick reflexes are good to have.  I have not beaten this game yet so I do not know how it ends. But, if odd pipeline-tunnel travel games are your thing, by all means, jump into the pipe and enjoy.
soo trippy an adictive

reviewText: Brainpipe came across as a first person Rez kind of game (which I love). But it's not. You don't shoot things. There's no sounds coming from objects. You just navigate through tunnels, avoiding objects and collecting glyphs. Each level has 10 to collect, but they're not mandatory to proceed to the next level. It just adds to your highscore in the end. I like the psychedelic graphics, they're done in a cool way, but that's about it. It's easy to play, but there's no real incentive to play this. There's nothing to do really, even beating other highscores isn't all that fun. Do with this what you will (which means; don't buy it).\n\n[Rating: 53/100]

reviewText:
While this magazine contains no brain or pipe, it certainly does contain a magnum orifice; known colloquially as a mindtube, which some hipsters refer to as a brainpipe. There's pleanty of brainpipe to be had in BRIANPUPE: Drive to Survive, but more importantly, there's more to be had in BRAINPIPE: A Plunge to unhumanity.

Both the gameplay and plot of BRAINPIPE combine together perfectly, this act of intercourse makes both of the major areas of this game a brilliant C+. You play as Filly the Dolphin as he explores the Kamino Sea's aquatic duct, which evently leads him to the magnum orifice. It's a rather thrilling adventure. I love getting into the Dolphin character while playing this game, the developers almost make you feel like you don't have to.



Overall, 3/10. I would have rated this game higher, but I'm aware individuals from North-Eastern Eroupe tend to enjoy this kind of novel.

reviewText: Brainpipe is a psychedelic game that will literally mind f*ck you. The feeling you get while playing this game is just abnormal and just flat out creepy and amazing at the same time. In this game you are basically a being floating through a tunneled space trying to avoid weird flying objects/obstacles while collecting floating dna. The real kicker is the graphics of this game, it’s very hypnotizing with the cool dark to grungy color. The sound effects on the background can put you in to a state of total relaxation. Honestly you just have to play it to see what I mean. This game is by far the “trippiest” game I have ever played. Do not play this game while you are high with your friends, much lulz would ensue.

Disclaimer: Ignore the playtime as it has not recorded properly I have infact poured many hours into this game.\nAn incredible, trippy, tube obstacle-dodging type of game where you fly through what I can only assume to be nerve pathways in the brain collecting neon glyphs for bonus points and seeing if you can reach the end to attain transcendence. The visuals are not complex but very pretty and fit the game very well, and the sound, THE SOUND, is just what makes this game so great. So immersive to play with a pair of headphones with great surround sound to trippy psychedelic noises and music that takes you on a mental journey. It sounds like I'm spouting a loud of metaphoric ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t but this is honestly a brilliant, unique game. Highly highly recommended it's so hard to do justice in words but it is honestly bloody fantastic!

Wow. That word sums up the feeling, the experience, the game...and though it may not be for everyone, I have the feeling of 'where have you been all my life', when enjoying Brainpipe. The premise is simple enough...go through ths first-person-perpective obstacle course, avoid all objects other than these heiroglyph symbols...yet it is challenging, and each playthrough feels different. The thing, though, is the visuals and the audio, as it is almost psychotropic, and even when you screw up you can feel the huge grin on your face, because the experience itself is like nothing I've seen(or heard, for that matter). I generally like runners or casual obstacle games, like 'The Collider' which is newer than this, or the runners like Race the Sun, TEC 3001 or FOTONICA, which are also newer. and all of those have somewhat 'trippy' visuals to add to the visceral feel in the games, but this has to be the king of trippy...sights and sounds dazzle you as you try to get through level 10 here and grab that heiroglyph if you can...and it certainly works for me. It probably is the kind of game to play in short spurts, as it can overwhelm the senses after a while, yet I find myself craving this game on occasion, and would caution against epileptics or folks seizure-prone playing this game. If ever there's a Brainpipe 2, however, count me in...and for two bucks you can find more potential thrills, huge grins and giddy laughter from the sensation, and reasons to play again, than for many top-dollar titles out there.

This was a game sitting on my Steam library due to some indie pack on sale for a good while. I wouldn't really say it's worth buying, especially for $10, but it certainly has it's merits.
The gameplay itself is... kind of standard, basically an extended Mario Party game, or maybe a flash game, although it's really difficult in the latter half of the game, being pretty hectic.
The graphics are pretty good, basically bacteria blob-looking things surrouding the tube you're going through, and bright vector (like the Vectrex, or Geometry Wars) graphics for the obstacles. They go pretty well with the atmosphere of the game and there aren't any problems like obstacles being hard to see. There isn't much to really say about them.
The music and sound effects create an excellent atmosphere, and I would definitely reccomend headphones if you're going to play it. There's a lot of speech in there as the game goes, and miscellaneous sound effects, which makes the levels slightly unsettling.

A Strange Game Where you travel through down pipes/levels of increasing difficulty. Your character is nothing more then a circle on the screen that you move around avoiding all the diffrent obstacles and collecting the glyphs in each level to increase your score. You can activate a short slow-mo ability for those tricky parts when you need to dodge a tough series of obstacles or get a gplyh. Its a unique experience with a surreal soundtrack and audio effects to accompany it simple but oddly engaing gameplay experience.
Incredibly short but a lot of fun and original! Beware though because i finished it in 20 minutes!

reviewText: Brainpipe: A Plunge to Unhumanity is an arcade game where you navigate harzards through a twisting psycadellic wormhole.  The graphics are very well done, as is the ambient accompanying music.  The developers also included native controller support which is welcome for any game that requires fast reflexes.  Ultimately the goal of the game is to pick up all the powerups you can and survive for 10 levels at which point you get to choose which alien form you take.  I have not made it this far into the game but I am intrigued enough to continue giving the game a try.  I would suggest that this is a solid purchase for anyone interest in indie arcade games.  I admit I was tickled when one of the ambient sounds that queued was the Dr.'s T.A.R.D.I.S. which I use as my profile icon.
Tripadelic brain tunnel arcade game.

That circle split into sections that you see in the screenshots; that's you ( a Third Eye, if you will). You navigate through the head to the brain from the nose collecting glyphs - sentiments, sensations, thoughts/ideas - avoiding everything else.

You'r body needs (the essence of/that is) YOU; does not want to see you cease to be you; transcend to UnHuman.

You (that circle) follow/guide the mouse cursor, click and hold to slow yourself - immune system (as it were) is unaffected.

reviewText: Do not purchase this game until they fix the crashes. Before OS X El Capitan, this game functioned fine. It no longer loads. It is a mesmerizing game to play, with stunning visuals. I sent numerous  requests this year without any response from the designers. If you can't fix it, have the Chinese or Japanese fix  it. They show more allegiance to their customers and honor their companies.

This game is simple on its essence: Deviate your route from objects while traveling through different 'mind regions'. The speed gets faster on each level, but you can slow time for a while to avoid colisions or to get 'the illuminated glyphs'. The sound is something like a mix of our everyday sounds on different ocasions. I think it´s a very interesting game.

You can train some mechanical reflex while having fun. :)
It is a bit short though.

Do not purchase this game until they fix the crashes. Before OS X El Capitan, this game functioned fine. It no longer loads. It is a mesmerizing game to play, with stunning visuals.
